page.title: 15MOUNT WELLINGTON MINE
page.content: Mount Wellington tin mine opened in the 1930's and closed in 1939, due to the war. It operated again from 1972- 78, then joined with Wheal Jane to re- open under new management in 1980. It produces about 300 tonnes of ore daily, which yields approx 2 tonnes of metal (600 tonnes a year). The ore goes under ground to Wheal Jane where it is crushed into concentrate and sold to the smelters at Hull. One tonne of tin is worth Â£10,000,and concentrate about Â£6,000, according to its purity. About 30 men are employed at the mine but it is illegal for women to work underground. All underground machinery is powered by compressed air except for battery operated rock-carriers. 4,000,000 gals of water a day are pumped through an adit into the Carnon River.
